I informed Sainsbury s I had paid 40p for 8 carrier bags ( @ 5p each) for an online shop but I only got 5.  You may have seen my post before it got taken off.  Their reply is below.  It appears you pay 40p even if you only get 1 bag   When agreeing to the carrier bag charge it is 40p for however many bags your shop needs. You don’t actually pay for a set amount of bags  do not choose how many you get and the amount you get is determined by your orders need for bags.    We now offer the option for you to choose whether you would like to have your order delivered with or without carrier bags. If you select not to receive bags you will not be charged the 40p carrier bag charge. You can select this option on the checkout page.  Our aim has always been to reduce the number of carrier bags used by our customers  reflecting the environmental objectives set out in the new legislation. We believe that our 5p reusable bags are the most effective way to do this  as they are made of recycled material and are recyclable plus we will replace them free of charge if they become damaged.  We also donate any profits we make from these reusable bags to good causes.  We do however  still provide single use carrier bags for online orders should a customer request their shopping be bagged. We will no longer have single use bags in our English stores as reusable bags are more environmentally friendly and we also believe that our customers will want something sturdier which they can reuse again and again.  We are therefore charging 5p for a reusable bag  in addition to our 10p bag for life. We will continue to use single use carrier bags for our online deliveries and will charge a flat fee of 40p per delivery.

Dear Sainsburys  At one of your stores today I wanted to buy a baby doll for my 18mth old son  so as to stop him constantly stealing his sister s ones. I was disappointed to see how gender stereotyped these dolls were and the choice so limited. We opted for a doll dressed fully in pink with a pink headband as the other choice was a baby dressed in pink or another one dressed in pink. I looked hopefully through the selection of clothes you could buy separately to dress the dolls  again  a pink sleep suit and a purple dress were my options.   Please understand that it is shops that drive the gender stereotyping of childrens toys  not those buying it.   In the real world there are baby boys as well as baby girls. Lots of babies are dressed in neutral coloured clothes or a whole rainbow of other colours (not just blue or pink). Dads look after babies as much as mums so this is not just a girl thing.  I am trying to bring up my children to understand that gender is not relevant in what they choose to do  but so many things surrounding them point otherwise. Perhaps you could consider my comments when looking for new stock.  Kind Regards  Hannah Ringrow

Dear Sainsbury s   I regularly buy my children s clothes from one of your stores which is local to where I live.  My children are two and four and have a range of interests from playing make believe with toys to outdoor sports and games.  I want them to be warm in the winter and cool in the summer with practical clothes that withstand the general wear and tear of climbing  running  swinging  playing in sand and everything else small children love to do.  They need to be washed after almost every wear due to splashed mud and paint  spilt food and unfortunately the occasional toileting accident.  My children like many colours and enjoy watching a wide variety of TV programmes and films from Pixar to CBeebies.  I am a grown woman in my 30s and I know my children and am able to differentiate between colours and characters that they like without somebody in a marketing department somewhere making arbitrary choices for me.  As a result  I am continually frustrated by the unhelpful way clothes are organised in my local Sainsbury s.  Children s clothes are separated into 3 different age categories as well as gender divides so if I m looking for warm practical trousers that can be worn in the winter months playing outside for both my children  there are 4 different sections I need to look through for me to find something suitable.  If all the trousers were in one place  it would actually make shopping a lot easier.  The gender divide in particular results in awful slogans perpetuating negative stereotypes such as girls are only valued on their appearance and boys are inherently naughty.  Some characters are only available on one gender or age range even though they might have universal appeal.  As an example  clothes with Paw Patrol on them only feature boy characters on the boys clothes and girl characters on the girls clothes.  I have read on another page that you have stated customer preference for arranging clothes as you do but I can honestly say this is not my preference.  Please can you look into organising all children s clothes according to type.  Both my children wear a range of clothes bought from the boys and the girls sections in a variety of shops as well as hand-me-downs from other boys and girls.  Children s body shapes are not that different until they reach puberty and in the interest of bringing up well rounded individuals  I try my hardest not to limit their interests with outdated attitudes.  I have worked in marketing myself and understand the various audience segmentation tools that companies use and how a microscopic focus on ROI leads many companies to treat them as gospel.  In my opinion  however  lazy use of gendered colours  images and slogans just leads to the perpetuation of potentially damaging stereotypes and in this day and age  particularly when it comes to children  I think any company that makes an example of themselves by taking a stand would actually reap far more benefit from a greater proportion of the population.  Kind regards   Lucy Forrest

We rushed over towards him  and whilst my sister pulled the bike off of him I rang for an ambulance. He was able to sit himself up  however he had gone face first  broke his helmet and smashed his glasses  so as you can imagine there was a lot of blood! I stayed with him whilst my sister went into the store to get more help  but she was met by a member of staff who simply handed her the emergency first aid bag and then wandered off. My sister then had to administer minimal treatment herself until the emergency response arrived! Once the emergency response came we moved inside and were given paperwork to fill out. For the rest of the duration from which the accident took place and the patient being taken to hospital in the ambulance  there was very minimal and poor communication from the 3 members of staff who we met. And we did all the paperwork! We asked the patient the questions  we got his details  we stayed with him until he was taken to the hospital  and we took his bike back to his address where his mum was very appreciative for all we did for him. And that s ok for us  we are both disabled and we appreciate what it means to have someone stop  stay  talk with and help in any way possible when an accident happens. But your staff were useless  showed no empathy and didn t care - that s just wrong. I cannot tell you how disappointed I am in Sainsbury s  for not taking care in their outside environment which tonight therefore resulted in an accident. I am also disappointed about their entire attitude towards the patient  ourselves and the emergency response staff on scene. We were in disbelief!!  I want to see that the drains are fixed so that this accident does not happen to someone else  and I want to make sure ALL staff who work for Sainsbury s are first aid trained. In the event of a life/death emergency  tonight  your staffs inability to deal with an emergency could result in someone s death... To the women who was on shift in the petrol station at Sainsburys in Tamworth at 7.45am on Thursday 17th November I would just like to let you know that my little boy has just today being discharged from hospital after transferred via ambulance to Walsgrave Hospital with suspected pnemonia.  My little boy took ill on Thursday so I phoned 111 who advised me to take him to the hospital. After seeing my little boy so poorly and being physically sick I jumped in my car and headed for A&E. On the way I noticed my petrol light was on so I pulled in to get fuel. I put £25.00 of fuel in and went to pay to find I hadn t picked my purse up...(Yes I should have checked I had means of payment which I thought was in my little boy bag however in the haste of the moment I must have forgot to pick it up as it wasn t!)  After informing the young women at the counter who was very  helpful  in informing me it was a criminal offence and that she would be calling the police who would Pursue me immediately I told her I had to leave and couldn t wait the 30 mins for her to ring the police and carry out the checks etc. I offered for my husband (who was 78 miles away racing down the m6 to meet me at the hospital) to pay over the phone via our joint account to which she replied it wasn t acceptable and someone needed to bring me the money or my purse. I then attempted to return to my car to get my little boy at which point she very loudly told me I couldn t and had to remain in the shop. Obviously I went to get my little boy out of the car to find him being violently sick everywhere. After returning to the shop and cleaning him up the best I could I told her I would be calling the police to tell them I was having to drive off and told them they would find me at the the A&E department. To the very kind young gentleman who offered to lend me the money to enable me to leave to take my little boy to get the help he needed thank you so much. You really are a life saver! I didn t know this chap from Adam and despite offering him my name  address and tel num he just took my num and said he would call me later - which he did and my husband left the money with the neighbour ready for him to collect.  Once the other women working in the Petrol station saw how poorly my little boy was they were very apologetic asking if they could do anything and apologising for adding stress to what was a very stressful situation for me. I know the staff have protocols to follow and I know I could have been pulling a fast one however they could clearly see I was distressed  upset and hopefully genuine. This is my local store  I hold a nectar card which although I didn t have on me it was in my purse I m sure she could have found me on the system somehow.  After speaking to people about my experience they have all said that if they have done it before or knew of someone who has done it they have had to fill a form in and take payment within 24 hours or face being reported to the police. Thankfully after being on a enebaliser for 2 days and then oxygen for a further 24 hours  2 chest X-rays  inhalers and antibiotics my little boy had a severe chest infection and bronchitis. Thankfully after his 2nd chest X-ray this morning it was confirmed he didn t have pneumonia.  We are now finally home but I would just like to show my sheer disgust to the young women in the petrol station that morning. I know I was 100% at fault for having no means of payment on me but there was certainly a better way of dealing with the matter in question! I will be speaking with the store manager but anyone in the same circumstances if you forget your purse expect to be embarrassed in front of a shop full of people and  spoken to by the staff of Sainsburys like a child!

I am writing to inform you that I will no longer be shopping at Sainsbury’s until your company withdraws all advertising from The Daily Mail newspaper. The Daily Mail and The Mail on Sunday’s editorial have behaved despicably in recent years by promoting messages of hatred towards vulnerable and minority groups. Help reduce plastic pollution in UK rivers and seas by asking retailers to switch own-brand cotton bud stems from plastic to paper.  Why is this important?  Plastic cotton bud stems are the number one item of plastic  sewage-related debris on our beaches and rivers [1] - yet retailers could help prevent this by switching the stick from plastic to paper.  In the marine environment  plastics can be eaten by marine life  often with fatal consequences. Plastic is found in the stomachs of Loggerhead Turtles  Seabirds and many species of UK-caught fish. And pieces that don t get eaten break down into microplastics  forming part of a dangerous plastic smog in our seas.  Retailers are listening - earlier this year  Waitrose and Johnson & Johnson announced they d make the change to paper  and the Coop and Marks and Spencers sell paper-stem buds. Now we need to make sure the others do the same.  Tesco  Sainsburys  Boots  ASDA  Morrisons  Lidl  Aldi  Superdrug and Wilko are currently reviewing their policies on cotton buds ... which is why we need to show them how many of us support the switch to paper!  Even paper stem cotton buds shouldn’t be flushed down the loo. But if they are  they re less likely to pass through sewage filters and will quickly biodegrade if they escape

My Blue Hands  I ve had an incident tonight that was both alarming and funny  and I d thought I would share it with you...  I ve been wearing the above jeans all day and I was delighted with my bargain after taking advantage of your recent 25% off offer  however things turned for the worse this evening....   Following a long conversation on my mobile with a friend  I ventured from my sofa to get myself a glass of wine from my kitchen  it was at this point I noticed my hands had turned blue! Luckily a friend was with me  and he looked concerned as he felt them and also said they were cold! Nervously I sat down and started to think something was not quite right. I shook them and rubbed them together but nothing changed the colour.... I did at the same time have a rather nasty pain in my back (which I have had for a couple of days) and I began to think this was linked!! I duly called NHS 111 for their advise. I spoke to an assistant who asked me a 1000 questions about my well being and she assured me I would now be referred to a clinical consultant  who would call back immediately. Anxiously I waited and within minutes I was now speaking with a very helpful medical professional. Again more questions were asked and I was advised to keep my hands above my head and if the colour didn t change it would be best to see my doctor in the morning!!.   My hands were not changing colour... I was worried  I hadn t eaten all day  and I d been in the same position all day doing my tax return  so my friend suggested I go to the fish and chip shop with him  maybe moving would make a difference to the clear lack of circulation... I duly followed his suggestion.  I returned home  could barely touch my fish and chips as I had lost my appetite as my fear grew as the colour hadn t changed at all.   I then called my best friends mum who was an ex nurse maybe she could re assure me! In the meantime my friend went to his van and retrieved a rather old but still functioning blood pressure reading machine. My friends mum asked a number of questions and got me to take my pulse. She then told me a similar incident happened to her daughter (my best friend) where they ended up at A and E  omg I was really getting scared now  and still my hands had not turned back to a normal colour!!!!!!   After assessing my condition once again  My friends mum did add that when she was in A and E they found out that in fact her blue hand condition was in fact the dye from her jeans.......  Yep  you guessed it!!!! I went to the bathroom washed my hands and low and behold the the lather from the soap started turning blue!!!!   Omg  I was so relieved that it was the dye from my new Sainsbury s jeggings and my life wasn t coming to an abrupt end....  I had suffered temporarily from  jegginginitious    Ha ha what a funny evening I ve had  but may I point out to you  that perhaps your dark blue skinny jeans and jeggings need to come with a health warning!!!!  Kind regards  Karren Kent
